Section Header:
Adverse Event Form 

README: This form is designed in conjunction with automated emails to improve efficiency for study staff and investigators. Leave the Form Status as Incomplete or Unverified until an AE is ready for closeout. Marking the form status as Complete will send an email to the investigator for final signature.

Field Label: How did we learn of this AE?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Phone | 2, In-Person Visit | 5, Other

Field Label:
AE Details / Narrative / Progress Note:

Please include a full, detailed narrative of the event. Provide as many details as possible so that any reviewer can fully grasp the situation. Be sure to track ongoing details until the event is completely resolved. For each new note, be sure to start a new line with the date of the note and end the note with initials. 

Guidance for questions to ask when gathering information

  • When did the event start?
  • How and where did the event occur?
  • If interventional study, when did the event begin in relation to the last dose of the intervention?
  • Is the event still on-going? If not, when did it cease?
  • Is the event persistent or does it come and go?
  • Was any treatment administered to alleviate the event? If so, what treatment (list meds, dose, when and how often taken)? Was the event alleviated by the treatment?
  • For pain-related AE's, may ask to rate pain on a scale of 1-10.
  • Did the event interfere with ability to complete daily activities? What type of activities? How was the participant limited? 
  • Did the participant seek care?
  • Did the participant go to the hospital? When? Where? Still there? Did they stay overnight? How long? What dates were they there? Be sure to consult study protocol for definition of hospitalization. 

Example for how to document AE and notes:

7/12/2023: Particpant rolled ankle on a stone while working in their garden at home in the afternoon on 7/11/23. Pt went to emergency care for imaging, which showed no structural damage. At doctor's suggestions, the pt has been icing, elevating, and using Advil. We were notified by phone on 7/12/2023. JC

7/29/2023: Pt feels symptoms have completely resolved. No longer feels pain in ankle and is able to walk without symptoms. Closing out AE. JC

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Yes | 0, No
Field Note: may select 1; if YES update concurrent medication log

Field Label: What action was taken with the study intervention?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Dose/Intervention not changed | 2, Dose/Intervention stopped | 3, Dose/Intervention interrupted | 4, Dose/Intervention modified

Field Label: Was AE ongoing at end of study?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Yes | 0, No
1, Recovered/Resolved | 2, Recovering/Resolving | 3, Not Recovered/Not Resolved | 4, Recovered/Resolved with sequelae | 5, Fatal | 6, Unknown

Field Label:
Severity

Generic CTCAE 5.0 grades are listed below. Be sure to consult your protocol and the CTCAE 5.0.


Grade 1 Mild; asymptomatic or mild symptoms; clinical or diagnostic observations only; intervention not indicated.


Grade 2 Moderate; minimal, local or noninvasive intervention indicated; limiting age-appropriate instrumental ADL*.


Grade 3 Severe or medically significant but not immediately life-threatening; hospitalization or prolongation of hospitalization indicated; disabling; limiting self care ADL**.


Grade 4 Life-threatening consequences; urgent intervention indicated.


Grade 5 Death related to AE
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Grade 1; Mild | 2, Grade 2; Moderate | 3, Grade 3; Severe | 4, Grade 4; Life Threatening | 5, Grade 5; Death related to AE

Field Label:
Relatedness

Suggested definitions using HSC and NIA guidance are provided below. Be sure to consult your protocol.

Definitely Related: The adverse event is clearly related to the investigational agent/procedure - i.e. an event that follows a reasonable temporal sequence from administration of the study intervention, follows a known or expected response pattern to the suspected intervention, that is confirmed by improvement on stopping and reappearance of the event on repeated exposure and that could not be reasonably explained by the known characteristics of the subject's clinical state.

Probably Related: The adverse event is more likely than not attributable to study participation, i.e. an adverse event that follows a reasonable temporal sequence from administration of the study intervention follows a known or expected response pattern to the suspected intervention, but that could readily have been produced by a number of other factors.

Not Related: The adverse event is judged to be caused by the clinical state or clearly attributable to unrelated circumstances.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 2, Definitely Related | 1, Probably related | 0, Not related

Field Label:
Expectedness

Standard HSC definitions of expectedness are below. Be sure to consult your study protocol and consent for expectedness. 

Expected: does NOT differ in nature, severity, or frequency from risk information previously reviewed by the IRB

Unexpected: differs in nature, severity, or frequency from risk information previously reviewed and approved by the IRB
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Expected | 0, Unexpected

Field Label: This AE is related or probably related and unexpected; therefore, this AE should be reported to the KUMC IRB. Be sure to use the Reporting Section below.
If Unexpected: What is the rationale?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, The event not described in available risk information currently | 2, The severity or frequency of the event was more than what was anticipated/described | 3, Other

Field Label:
Is this a Serious Adverse Event?

Guidelines for serious adverse events are below, but be sure to consult your study protocol.

Any adverse event that:
• Results in death
• Is life threatening, or places the participant at immediate risk of death from the event as it occurred
• Requires or prolongs hospitalization
• Causes persistent or significant disability or incapacity
• Results in congenital anomalies or birth defects
• Is another condition which investigators judge to represent significant hazards
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Yes | 0, No
1, Death | 2, Life threatening | 3, Hospitalization | 4, Disability or permanent damage | 5, Congenital anomaly/birth defect | 6, Other serious (important medical events)

Field Label: Date of Initial PI signature on AE form

Section Header:
Reporting Section

All internal adverse drug, device, and other events, serious or non-serious, that are unexpected and that are judged by the KUMC principal investigator to be related or probably related to participation in the research should be reported.

To review the updated KUMC guidance for reporting, see section 5.3 in this link to IRB SOP 05.0 Reviews of Ongoing Research.

Time Frames for reporting (see section 5.3.VI of IRB SOP 05.0 Reviews of Ongoing Research)

  1. Except for study deaths, internal problems must be reported to the IRB within five working days.
  2. For study deaths, see SOP Section 5.3.VI.C. Minimum reporting time is 24 hours, but reporting time depends on the situation.

Report Form (see section 5.3.VII of IRB SOP 05.0 Reviews of Ongoing Research)

  1. Investigators report the above listed problems using the eIRB system function of "Reportable New Information."
  2. A PDF of this adverse event may be submitted with the RNI as the required supplemental reporting form.

Last update: 07-21-2023

Please review and update if last update is out of date.

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, PI determined AE not related to study treatment/procedure | 2, PI determined AE was related to the study, but was an expected event (is consistent with available risk information)

Field Label:
Final Investigator's Signature (PI)

The Investigator has reviewed this AE and is signing to confirm completion.

Summary of AE for DSMC Report

This field will be used in the automated DSMC reporting. Please give a condensed (1-3 sentences) narrative of the AE. This field should be updated before DSMC reporting as well as when the AE has been closed out.
Optional file upload, i.e. physician clearance, etc.

Section Header:
Instructions

This DSMC reporting tool contains every variable necessary to produce repeatable, automated DSMC reports.

  1. DO NOT change variable names in this instrument. These variables must retain their names for the automated reporting to work properly.
  2. It's possible your project already contains some of these variables. If so, we recommend replacing your existing variable with the variable in this instrument.
  3. You may move the variables in this instrument into other instruments to better fit workflow. Just be sure to keep names.
Field Label:
Group

 

NOTE: You can change the groups to match your study. For now, the code will only recognize two arms. We are working to allow for more than two groups.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Weight Loss | 2, Control
1, Male | 2, Female | 3, Unknown

1, Eligible | 2, Screen-Fail | 3, On-hold

Examples of Violations

  • affects the rights and welfare of the subject(s).
  • affects the integrity of the research data.
  • increases the risk of harm for one or more subjects.
  • caused actual harm.

Type of Deviation

1, Study Team | 2, Sponsor Monitor / Auditor | 3, KUMC Quality Assurance Review | 4, Other

Field Label:
IRB Reporting Information

Reporting Form

Do not meet the IRB reporting criteria:

  • Study visits occurring outside the protocol required time frame due to participant schedule
  • Study activities performed close to, but not precisely at the time points specified in the protocol.

Meet the IRB reporting criteria:

  • Failure to obtain informed consent or re-consent when required by the IRB.
  • Modifying the protocol without IRB approval, except to avoid immediate hazard to subjects.
  • Conducting the research prior to IRB approval, during an IRB suspension or after IRB approval ends.

  • Noncompliance affects the rights and welfare of the subject(s).
  • Noncompliance affects the integrity of the research data.
  • Noncompliance increases the risk of harm for one or more subjects.
  • Noncompliance caused actual harm.

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Failure to obtain informed consent or re-consent when required by the IRB. | 2, Modifying the protocol without IRB approval, except to avoid immediate hazard to subjects. | 3, Conducting the research prior to IRB approval, during an IRB suspension or after IRB approval ends. | 4, Noncompliance affects the rights and welfare of the subject(s). | 5, Noncompliance affects the integrity of the research data. | 6, Noncompliance increases the risk of harm for one or more subjects. | 7, Noncompliance caused actual harm. | 8, Other
